pr_title: Enable IOSQE_ASYNC depending on how many fds are handled

timeline.message:
Enable IOSQE_ASYNC depending on how many fds are handled

Motivation:

It has shown in benchmarks that IOSQE_ASYNC can be harmful when there
are not a lot of fds handled at the same time.

Modifications:

- Dont use IOSEQ_ASYNC for IORING_IO_TIMEOUT, IORING_IO_POLLADD,
IORING_IO_POLLREMOVE
- Enable / disable the usage of IOSEQ_ASYNC for others IO ops based on
the number of fds that are handled

Result:

Better performance without the need of the user to tune things

timeline.bodyText: this was the number after which using the flag showed good results here...
timeline.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: let's use a sys prop here? That would be nice to help with tests
replies.author: franz1981

timeline.bodyText: No need to compute the sqeFlagsAddress anymore. The variable isn't used.
timeline.author: chrisvest

timeline.bodyText: I think you don't want to increment here in the case that channels.put returns non-null, right?
timeline.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: I think I actually want as I also always decrement... below. I am missing something ?
replies.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: Maybe this isn't possible for other sequencing reasons, but what if the same fd is replaced 3 times in succession.. then count will be +3. Then when removed it will only be -1 since it's only decremented once (if called multiple times only the first will decrement). So we end up with no fd but still a positive count. I could also be missing something :)
replies.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: Ok maybe the multiple case is not possible but you are saying that the put will never overwrite? If so what is the purpose of this check after remove https://github.com/netty/netty/pull/10625/files#diff-edc47287cb4c12155b5456eb05260bcbR118-R125?
replies.author: njhill

replies.bodyText: You are right ... I guess I should only increment here if null is returned and only decrement if we not put back the channel in the remove method ... WDYt ?
replies.author: normanmaurer

replies.bodyText: Yes I think if you just increment here if null is returned from put then the decrement can stay as you have it
replies.author: njhill
